hints_html:
The definition of a derivative is

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\)

Alternatively, one can use

\(\displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a}\)

At some stage, you might want to find a common denominator for two fractions you are trying to subtract.
hints_latex:
The definition of a derivative is

$\displaystyle f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}$

Alternatively, one can use

$\displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a}$

At some stage, you might want to find a common denominator for two
fractions you are trying to subtract.
hints_raw:
The definition of a derivative is

<math> \displaystyle f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}</math>

Alternatively, one can use

<math> \displaystyle f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a}</math>
At some stage, you might want to find a common denominator for two fractions you are trying to subtract.
sols_html:
By the definition of a derivative, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{x+h}{x + h + 5} - \frac{x}{x+5} }{h} \end{aligned}\]

The key step to simplifying this expression is here: we find a common denominator for the fractions on top and combine them.

\[\begin{aligned} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{(x+h)(x+5)}{(x + h + 5)(x+5)} - \frac{x(x+h+5)}{(x+h+5)(x+5)} }{h} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{x^{2} + xh + 5x + 5h - x^{2} - xh - 5x}{(x + h + 5)(x+5) }}{h} \end{aligned}\]

Now we simplify the expression into a single fraction and cancel the h on top and bottom.

\[\begin{aligned} &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{5h}{h(x + h + 5)(x+5)} \\ &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{5}{(x + h + 5)(x+5)} \end{aligned}\]

Finally taking the limit gives:

\[\begin{aligned} &= \frac{5}{(x + 5)(x+5)} \\ &= \frac{5}{(x + 5)^{2}} \end{aligned}\]

Using the alternative definition,

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a} \\ f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{x}{x+5} - \frac{a}{a+5}}{x-a} \end{aligned}\]

Here we find a common denominator to simplify the fractions on top of the large fraction.

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{x(a+5)}{(x+5)(a+5)} - \frac{a(x+5)}{(a+5)(x+5)}}{x-a} \\ f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{xa+5x - ax - 5a}{(x+5)(a+5)} }{x-a} \end{aligned}\]

We then simplify the fraction, factoring out a 5 on top and then canceling the (x - a) term.

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5x - 5a}{(x+5)(a+5)(x-a)} \\ f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5(x - a)}{(x+5)(a+5)(x-a)} \\ f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5}{(x+5)(a+5)} \end{aligned}\]

Finally we take the limit.

\[\begin{aligned} f'(a) &= \frac{5}{(a+5)(a+5)} \\ f'(a) &= \frac{5}{(a+5)^{2}} \end{aligned}\]

Which completes the question.
sols_raw:
By the definition of a derivative, we have that

<math>
\begin{align}
f'(x) &= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h}\\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{x+h}{x + h + 5} - \frac{x}{x+5} }{h} \end{align}</math>

The key step to simplifying this expression is here: we find a common denominator for the fractions on top and combine them.  

<math>\begin{align}
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{(x+h)(x+5)}{(x + h + 5)(x+5)} - \frac{x(x+h+5)}{(x+h+5)(x+5)} }{h} \\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{\frac{x^{2} + xh + 5x + 5h - x^{2} - xh - 5x}{(x + h + 5)(x+5) }}{h} \end{align}</math>

Now we simplify the expression into a single fraction and cancel the ''h'' on top and bottom.  

<math>\begin{align}
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{5h}{h(x + h + 5)(x+5)} \\
&= \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{5}{(x + h + 5)(x+5)} \end{align}</math>

Finally taking the limit gives: 

<math>\begin{align}
&= \frac{5}{(x + 5)(x+5)} \\
&= \frac{5}{(x + 5)^{2}} 
\end{align}
</math>
Using the alternative definition,

<math>
\begin{align}
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x) - f(a)}{x-a} \\
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{x}{x+5} - \frac{a}{a+5}}{x-a} \end{align} </math>

Here we find a common denominator to simplify the fractions on top of the large fraction.  

<math>
\begin{align} f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{x(a+5)}{(x+5)(a+5)} - \frac{a(x+5)}{(a+5)(x+5)}}{x-a} \\
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{\frac{xa+5x - ax - 5a}{(x+5)(a+5)} }{x-a} \end{align}
</math>

We then simplify the fraction, factoring out a 5 on top and then canceling the ''(x - a)'' term.  

<math>
\begin{align}
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5x - 5a}{(x+5)(a+5)(x-a)} \\
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5(x - a)}{(x+5)(a+5)(x-a)} \\
 f'(a) &= \lim_{x \to a} \frac{5}{(x+5)(a+5)} \end{align}
</math>

Finally we take the limit.  

<math>
\begin{align}
 f'(a) &= \frac{5}{(a+5)(a+5)} \\
 f'(a) &= \frac{5}{(a+5)^{2}} \\
\end{align}
</math>

Which completes the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Find the derivative of the function

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{t}{t+5}\end{aligned}\]

using the definition of the derivative.

NOTE: No credit will be given for using differentiation rules such as the power rule, product rule, quotient rule or chain rule, although you may use these rules to check your answer.
statement_raw:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly requested.

Find the derivative of the function

:<math>
\frac{t}{t+5}
</math>

using the definition of the derivative.

''NOTE: No credit will be given for using differentiation rules such as the power rule, product rule, quotient rule or chain rule, although you may use these rules to check your answer.''
